A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain for 3 months. The pain is radiating to the right leg with numbness up to his foot. Pain is continuous, and bowel and bladder functions are intact. He has a history of hypertension for the past 14 years. On examination, the right straight leg raise test is 60 degrees, and the left is 90 degrees. Sciatic nerve stretch is negative, right piriformis test is positive, and Faber test is negative. Reflexes and myotomes are intact with dermatomes, and the heel and toe walk test are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Caused by reactivation of virus in dorsal root ganglion

Immediately dress it to protect it from external environment

question: A 16-year-old boy visited the skin clinic with a complaint of gradual hair loss for 3 months. On examination, he had greasy yellow fine scales on the scalp associated with an itchy erythematous scaly rash on eyebrows, nasolabial fold, upper chest, and back. What is the clinical diagnosis?

An infant was brought to the skin clinic with a complaint of rash in the diaper area. On examination, the baby had well-demarcated erythema, edema, dryness, and scaling of the areas covered under the diaper with sparing of the skin folds. There were no pustules, stellate lesions, or any involvement of the other body areas. What is the clinical diagnosis?
